sub_topic: Identifying the Lewis structure of a molecule
message_1: What is the Lewis structure of the molecule BrF5?
message_2:
To draw the Lewis structure of BrF5 (Bromine Pentafluoride), follow these steps:

1. Count the total number of valence electrons: Bromine (Br) has 7 valence electrons, and Fluorine (F) has 7 valence electrons. Since there are 5 Fluorine atoms, the total number of valence electrons is 7 (Br) + 5 * 7 (F) = 42 valence electrons.

2. Identify the central atom: Bromine (Br) is the central atom in BrF5, as it is the least electronegative element in the molecule.

3. Place the central atom and connect the surrounding atoms with single bonds: Place Br in the center and connect it to the 5 F atoms with single bonds. This uses up 10 valence electrons (5 single bonds * 2 electrons per bond).

4. Distribute the remaining valence electrons as lone pairs: There are 32 valence electrons left (42 - 10). Place 3 lone pairs (6 electrons) on the Br atom and 6 lone pairs (12 electrons) on each F atom, so that each F atom has an octet configuration.

5. Check if the central atom has an octet configuration: Bromine has an expanded octet configuration, as it has 5 single bonds and 3 lone pairs, which totals to 10 electrons around it. This is acceptable because Br is in the 4th period of the periodic table and can accommodate more than 8 electrons.

The Lewis structure of BrF5 is:

          F
          |
F - Br - F
          |
          F
          |
          F
